title: TOMSY - Topology Based Motion Synthesis for Dexterous Manipulation

author: Danica Kragić, School of Computer Science and Communication, KTH - Royal Institute of Technology

segmentation: So Tom ZI in regarding to Tom Z.
So I'm volts coordinator of grass, but I'm coordinator of Clumsy and I don't suggest anybody to coordinate two projects at the same time, but grasp is finished so I can concentrate fully on tamsi.
Rosie is a strap running for three years and stands for topology based motion synthesis for dexterous manipulation.
So I will now try to show you how to see is different from grasp.
And don't see has five partners us from Sweden to partners from UK and then partners from Spain and Germany.
And it started in April 2011.
So we have been going on for about 10 months now.
Now you have heard lots about grasping and of course grasping.
Yes we sold some things.
We solve them nicely.
I dare to say an, but there are still many things that humans are excellent in doing and the robots that we've seen today and that we know of are still not able to do.
One of the things that humans are very good in doing is to use or find a way of how to adapt an to change in morphology too.
If something is missing, for example of finger, or if we have maybe injured other arm, we can still execute most of the things that we are used to do on everyday basis.
Tying shoelaces might be a little bit different.
If you really enjoy your hand and so on, but we somehow manage now.
The idea of Toms.

It was when it was born in the beginning it was really to try to understand how to do full body motion and how to control complex bodies, but then also bodies that are in interaction with each others and but this is also why this was important.
It was not only for robotics but also for game industry.
So for example if you want to have.
Examples of.
Different types of games where two entities or two bodies are interacting with each other.
The state of the art is still that very complex.
Motions.
For example, doing this basically going from.
Disposition to that position, which will usually see is that your gaming software is allowing for penetration.

Now this is something that we cannot allow in robotics and we need very good motion planners and they need to take into consideration of course the full kinematics and dynamics of the bodies that are interacting.
So the approach for Tom Z for us was really to look into some of the state of the art.

Mathematical modeling aspects of how we can use topology and homology as you see here to really deal with high dimensional spaces in which there are some so called hard constraints and hard constraints.
Of course, of course, and given by different limbs or different.
Parts of parts of bodies.
So what we wanted to do was to use the topology based representation for dealing with this.
With this problem.

Now, one of the things that we have been doing for the past eight months was to look into what's there in mathematics that we can just bring to robotics that can help us to solve some of these problems, and it's really interesting to talk to and work with mathematicians.
It's a challenge.
Also because we have a very difficult understanding of the assumptions that can be made when we set out to develop these methods.
So the one of the things that we are working on now is looking into how, for example, we can use the different types of topological representations.
How we can use them in order to learn distributions in high dimensional spaces and how we can do regression on those.
I'm not going to go into details about the organization of the project that we have partners that are doing robotics.
We have partners from the Mechatronics at are looking into how we can use the apology for building so called metamorphic mechanisms.
So self free or reconfigurable hands.
And then we also have people from the gaming industry that are looking into how this planning.
A planning software can be used for building more net.
Troll or more realistic games?
A couple of objectives.
But I think it's also now trying to some of the things that we have done in grasp is really understanding and how humans are solving some of these tasks.
Measuring human motion and to some extent using it.
Is it as inspiration to see really how complex the data that we can generate can really get?
Now a number of work packages.
For here, so just to give you a little bit of a flavor for what these are all about.
An hand tracking is Antonius.
Can I hope witness that the very high dimensional problems, specially when we talk about two hands interacting with an object that is maybe even deformable?
So if you are really tying a shoelace or you are tying a knot.

And then imagine if you now add actually the whole body and in many cases apart from again using our upper body, we are using the whole body to, let's say compensate for some of the problems that like pain in upper back and so on.
So what we're looking at is how this topological representations can be used for doing better tracking.
So basically constraining the state space for the hand or full full body tracker.
Some initial work has been done on this and we are now looking into how we can reuse or use basically the same type of representation for both tracking and.
And planning motion planning.

And when we talk about the apologies, we can talk about both continuous and discrete spaces, different types of representations can be used for, for example, understanding that these two images are, well, same or different.
It depends a little bit as you see them.
And I think that for those that know something about the topology and the famous statement that apologists cannot actually see or realize the difference between a donut and a Cup.
Tells tells a lot.
When it comes to metamorphic mechanisms, how topology can help?

Well, it can help to tell to the hand to reconfigure itself on demand depending on the dimensionality of the problem, and this is where we are looking into how we can design problem and different types of fingers that can again be moving.
For static dependent on the task that hand is supposed to execute.
It.
And of course, the integration evaluation and benchmarking as in the rest of the projects that we have heard about today.
Now what is interesting for us is really the use or understand the use of hand when people are interacting with rigid, articulated or deformable object.
So I hope that in a year or year and a half I'll come back and give you also some really nice movies of how.
What we learned.
So I invite you to look at the web page and some of the publications and videos that we have so far.
So thank you.
